facts.text: Petition No. 683 of 1951 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: Petition  No. 683 of 1951  under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on February 15, 1951 under detention order dated February 13, 1951 by District Magistrate, Surat under Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On February 15, 1951, the petitioner was arrested under an order made on February 13, 1951, by the then District Magistrate, Surat, in exercise of powers companyferred on him by the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

facts.text: Copy of detention order served on petitioner at time of arrest on February 15, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: A companyy of the said order was served on the petitioner at the time of his ar- rest.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on petitioner on February 15, 1951 as required by section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date grounds of detention were served on the petitioner as required by section 7 of the Act.

facts.text: Grounds mentioned it was not in public interest to disclose further facts.

anchor.surface_text: It was specifically mentioned in the grounds that it was number in the public interest to disclose further facts.

facts.text: Petitioner moved Bombay High Court under Article 226 complaining detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner moved the High Court of Bombay under article 226 of the Constitution companyplaining that his detention was illegal and praying that he should be forthwith released.

facts.text: Petitioner urged in Bombay HC that grounds were false, vague, fantastic and detention in bad faith.

anchor.surface_text: In that appli- cation one of the points urged was that the grounds in support of the detention were false, vague and fantastic and that the detention order was made in bad faith.

facts.text: Two affidavits filed by State in Bombay HC in support of detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Two affida- vits were filed on behalf of the State in support of the detention order.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed petitioner's application on April 17, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: That application was, on April 17, 1951, dismissed by the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Advisory Board made report on April 5, 1951 stating sufficient cause for detention.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime, the case of the petitioner was placed before the Advisory Board which on Aprils, 1951, made a report stating that in its opinion there was sufficient cause for the detention of the petitioner.

facts.text: Government decided on April 13, 1951 to confirm the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit of Venilal Tribho- vandas Dehejia, Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, filed in answer to the present application, this report of the Advisory Board was placed before the Govern- ment and, on April 13, 1951, the Government decided to companyfirm the order of detention.

facts.text: Confidential letter dated April 28, 1951 from Home Department to District Magistrate, Surat confirming detention order.

anchor.surface_text: This decision was, on April 28, 1951, companymunicated to the District Magistrate, Surat, in a companyfidential letter in the terms following -- Confidential letter No. B.D. II/1042-D  11  Home Department  Political  Bombay Castle, To 28th April, 1951.

facts.text: Letter informed detenu of confirmation and to report compliance.

anchor.surface_text: Government is accordingly pleased to companyfirm the detention order issued against the detenu. Please inform the detenu accordingly and report companypliance.

facts.text: Letter signed by G.K. Kharkar for Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: Sd -G, K. Kharkar, for Secretary to the Government of Bom- bay, Home Department.

facts.text: G.K. Kharkar was Assistant Secretary authorized under rule 12 of Rules of Business under Article 166.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears from the aforesaid affidavit that Sri K. Kharkar who signed the letter for the Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, was at the time an Assistant Secretary and, as such, was, under rule 12 of the Rules of Business made by the Government of Bombay under article 166 of the Constitution, authorised to sign orders and instruments of the Government of Bombay.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Venilal Tribhovandas Dehejia, Secretary to Government of Bombay, Home Department.

anchor.surface_text: According to the affidavit of Venilal Tribho- vandas Dehejia, Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Home Department, filed in answer to the present application,

facts.text: Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Article 32 complaining unlawful detention.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner has number moved this Court under article 32 of the Constitution companyplaining that he is being unlawfully detained.

facts.text: Petitioner in illegal detention in Baroda Central Prison.

anchor.surface_text: for the immediate release of the petitioner who is alleged to have been kept in illegal detention in Baroda Central Prison.

facts.text: Supplementary petition filed complaining grounds false, vague, lacking particulars.

anchor.surface_text: Although a supplementary petition has been filed in this Court companyplaining that the grounds supplied to him are false, vague, lacking in particulars and insufficient to enable the petitioner to make an effective representation against the order of detention,

facts.text: Arguments in Supreme Court confined to two grounds: no period specified in confirmation under s.11(1), confirmation not in name of Governor under Art.166(1).

anchor.surface_text: At the hearing before us, learned companynsel has companyfined his arguments to challeng- ing the validity of detention of the petitioner on two grounds, namely,  1  that the State Government has failed to companyply with the requirements of section 11 1  of the amended Act in that at the time of companyfirming the detention order it omitted to specify the period during which the detention would companytinue, and  2  that the order of companyfirmation is number in proper legal form, in that it is number expressed to be made in the name of the Governor as required by article 166  1  of -the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: 1952. March 27. The Court delivered judgment as fol- lows-- DAS J.

facts.text: Petition dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above, in my opinion, this appli- cation must fail.

facts.text: Patanjali Sastri C.J., Mukherjea J., Chandrasekhara Aiyar J. agreed with Das J.

issues.text: The validity of the detention of the petitioner has been challenged before us on a two-fold ground. The first ground urged is that it was imperative on the part of the appropriate Government, when it confirmed the order of detention under section 11(1) of the Preventive Detention Act, to specify the period during which the detention was to continue

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the detention of the petitioner has been challenged before us on a two-fold ground. The first ground urged is that it was imperative on the part of the appropri-

issues.text: The other contention raised is that the order of confirmation not being expressed to be made in the name of the Governor, as is required under article 166(1) of the Constitution, is void and inoperative.

anchor.surface_text: The other contention raised is that the order of confirma- tion number being expressed to be made in the name of the Governor, as is required under article 166 1 of the Con- stitution, is void and inoperative.

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 166 directory, not mandatory; omission does not invalidate executive decision if taken.

arguments.claim: Section 11(1) of the Act contemplates only the taking of an executive decision to confirm the detention order; does not require specifying the period or formal order.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General urges that section 11 1 of the Act contemplates only the taking of an executive decision, namely. the confirmation of the detention order and contends that the sub-section does not contemplate the making of a formal order.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t it is number expressed to be made in the name of the Governor as required by article 166  1  of -the Constitution. Ground No. 1. The validity of thi

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; confirmation decision suffices, no need for period specification.

arguments.claim: Omission to express executive decision in the form of article 166 does not make it illegal; provisions are directory, not mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Attorney-General then falls back upon the plea that an omission to make and authenticate an executive decision in the form mentioned in article 166 does not make the decision itself illegal, for the provisions of that article, like their counterpart in the Government of India Act, are merely directory and not mandatory

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a deci- sion as to whether the detention order should be companyfirmed or number under section 11  1 . That such a decision has been in fact taken by

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions creating public duties are directory; no prejudice if decision taken.

arguments.claim: Section 11(1) does not require specification of period; grammatically confers two powers: confirm and continue; continuation automatic post-confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: The argument is that the sub-section contemplates a decision containing two things, namely, 1 a confirmation of the detention order and 2 a direction for the continuation of the detention. I do not think this argument is sound, for if the intention were that both the things should be included in an order then the sub-section would have been worded differently.

arguments.claim: No need to specify period in s.11(1) as Act is temporary; detention ends with Act; cites Gopalan and Krishnan.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the notion that no specification of the period will continue the detention for an indefinite period need not oppress us unduly, because the Act itself being of a limited duration such detention must necessarily come to an end on the expiry of the Act.

arguments.claim: Article 166 directory; strict compliance not essential to validity; cites J.K. Gas Plant.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of that article, like their counterpart in the Government of India Act, are merely directory and not mandatory as held in J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co. Rampur Ltd. and Others v. The King-Emperor.

arguments.claim: Specification of period in s.11(1) desirable but omission does not make order nullity due to temporary nature of Act.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the fact that the new Preventive Detention Act is a temporary statute which was to be in force only up to the 1st of April, 1952... I am inclined to hold that no-specification of the further period in an order under section 11(1) of the Act does not make the order of detention a nullity.

arguments.claim: Article 166(1) directory; non-compliance loses immunity but does not invalidate order.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of clauses 1 and 2 of article 166 are directory and not mandatory in the sense that even if a particular order is not expressed or authenticated in the way mentioned in these provisions, it would not be an ineffective or invalid order

arguments.claim: Section 11 requires specification of period; words 'such period as it thinks fit' imply government must fix period; failure makes detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The words such period as it thinks fit have the meaning that government has to specify and fix the period of such detention... After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenu's and makes the detention illegal.

holdings.text: On a proper construction of section 11(1), a specification of the period of continuation of the detention is not necessary.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, on a proper construction of section 11 1 , a specification of the period of continuation of the deten- tion is number necessary, however desirable one may companysider it to be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Grammatical analysis shows two separate powers: confirm and continue; continuation automatic post-confirmation; temporary Act limits duration; precedents in Gopalan and Krishnan apply.

holdings.text: Article 166(1) provisions are directory and not mandatory; omission to express executive decision in the name of the Governor does not render it invalid.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of that article, like their counterpart in the Government of India Act, are merely directory and not mandatory as held in J.K. Gas Plant Manufacturing Co. Rampur Ltd. and Others v. The King-Emperor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions create public duties; strict compliance causes inconvenience without promoting object; precedent from Federal Court; loss of immunity but not invalidity.

holdings.text: The appropriate Government took an executive decision to confirm the detention order under section 11(1), satisfying the procedure established by law.

anchor.surface_text: That such a decision has been in fact taken by the appropriate Government is amply proved on the record. Therefore, there has been, in the circumstances of this case, numberbreach of the procedure established by law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit evidence shows Government decision on April 13, 1951; communicated via authorized officer; no formal order form required by Act.

holdings.text: No breach of procedure established by law; detention valid.

anchor.surface_text: and the present detention of the petitioner cannot be called in question. For the reasons stated above, in my opinion, this appli- cation must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both challenges rejected; procedure under Preventive Detention Act followed.

holdings.text: Omission to specify period under section 11(1) does not make detention order a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: having regard to the fact that the new Preventive Detention Act is a temporary statute which was to be in force only up to the 1st of April, 1952... I am inclined to hold that no-specification of the further period in an order under section 11(1) of the Act does not make the order of detention a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Temporary nature limits duration; implies continuation till Act expiry; no prejudice.

holdings.text: Article 166(1) is directory; order valid despite not expressed in Governor's name.

anchor.surface_text: the provisions of clauses 1 and 2 of article 166 are directory and not mandatory in the sense that even if a particular order is not expressed or authenticated in the way mentioned in these provisions, it would not be an ineffective or invalid order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formality for public acts; non-compliance loses protection but proves actual authority.

holdings.text: Words 'such period as it thinks fit' in section 11(1) oblige Government to specify and fix the period of detention; failure makes detention illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The words such period as it thinks fit have the meaning that government has to specify and fix the period of such detention... After considerable thought I have reached the conclusion that the non-determination by Government of the period of the continuance of the detention operates prejudicially against the detenu's and makes the detention illegal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation requires fixing period; indefinite detention repugnant; onus on State undischarged. (Dissenting view)

having regard to the fact that the new Preventive Detention Act is a temporary statute which was to be in force only up to the 1st of April, 1952... I am inclined to hold that no-specification of the further period in an order under section 11(1) of the Act does not make the order of detention a nullity.
The result is that both the grounds fail and the petition is dismissed.

the provisions of clauses 1 and 2 of article 166 are directory and not mandatory in the sense that even if a particular order is not expressed or authenticated in the way mentioned in these provisions, it would not be an ineffective or invalid order
